title: Celtic boss Brendan Rodgers is calling for referees to clampdown on reckless challenges | Football News | Sky Sports
text:
Celtic boss Brendan Rodgers is calling for referees to clampdown on reckless challenges Last Updated: 23/02/17 4:03pm Kieran Tierney required treatment after a tackle to his knee Celtic boss Brendan Rodgers has indicated he will seek assurances over the protection of his players from the Scottish Football Association. 
Left-back Kieran Tierney, who recently returned to action after ankle and shoulder surgery, was left in a heap floowing a challenge by Motherwell's Ryan Bowman, which resulted in a yellow card for the forward. 
Although Tierney was able to complete the 90 minutes of Celtic's 2-0 victory, the 19-year-old had a badly gashed knee. John Kennedy and Celtic boss Brendan Rodgers earlier this season 
And in the recent 6-0 Scottish Cup fifth-round win over Inverness CT, Iain Vigurs was booked after a two-footed challenge on Celtic winger Scott Sinclair. 
Rodgers fears one of his players will be seriously injured, and he would be happy to voice concerns on the matters by speaking to SFA Head of Referees John Fleming. 
The Hoops manager is alarmed a Scottish player could have his career ended prematurely in the manner of John Kennedy, who is now a defensive coach at the club. 
Kennedy, who was making his Scotland debut in 2004 against Romania at the age of 20, was caught by a late knee-high challenge from Ionel Ganea, and never fully recovered before retiring from the game five years later. Celtic defender Kieran Tierney was able to continue despite a tackle to his knee 
"I would like them to have a sense of just a wee bit of protection for our players," Rodgers said, who asked about his thoughts on Scottish match officials. 
"I see the tackle on Kieran Tierney, which I didn't get a chance to see last week straight after the game, I didn't see it. But I've watched the replay afterwards, and it was a horrendous challenge. 
"Now this is a kid who is coming through, he's 19-years-of-age, one of the great prospects of Scottish football. I've a boy who is a brilliant coach on my staff, John Kennedy, who was also a brilliant prospect, who in one challenge lost his career. 
"I don't really want that to happen to any of my players or any player for that fact, whether he's from Celtic, Rangers, Hearts, Hibs, wherever." Also See:
